title: Account hacked, using my RP to gift himself skins
body:
Hi,

I don't know where else to seek support but here.

I'd like to notify that today when I logged into the client, there was a notification that says 'Im Shaco GG has received xx skin' 4 times. I have never heard of this name 'Im Shaco GG' and is not in my friends list. When I wanted to buy a skin, I discovered that my 3000 - 4000 RP is depleted. 

It dawned on me that somehow this person must've hacked my account and gifted himself skins.

I check my gifting history and true enough this is the case.

I have since changed my password.

Riot, how do I get back my RP and prevent this from happening again? I am now afraid of purchasing RP because this might happen again.

replies.body:
As *LordYeven* mentioned, you'll want to create a [support ticket](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/requests/new) so our account specialists can look into this with you.

Let me know if you have any other questions.

Hey, hope you see this.

http://66.media.tumblr.com/96be2a79e4dc406e84fe3d83f9f4f22b/tumblr_nwwjxlwwNd1uc4xwdo1_540.png

(saw how busy you've been working to help people) :D

> [{quoted}](name=zacharoo77,realm=NA,application-id=osqw6G4M,discussion-id=P2mZP9XN,comment-id=,timestamp=2016-10-02T17:46:14.600+0000)

I have never heard of this name &#039;Im Shaco GG&#039; and is not in my friends list. When I wanted to buy a skin, I discovered that my 3000 - 4000 RP is depleted. 
> 
> It dawned on me that somehow this person must&#039;ve hacked my account and gifted himself skins.
>

> 
> I have since changed my password.
> 
> Riot, how do I get back my RP and prevent this from happening again? I am now afraid of purchasing RP because this might happen again.

BIs
I mean after all bud your real name is Peter right?

As we can't assist you with these sort of issues on the Boards, we suggest you [submit a ticket](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/requests/new) to Player Support. They'll be able to look into the issue and give you further assistance.
However be aware that you are 100% responsible for things happening on your account.

To prevent this: make sure you logout every single time, do not choose a weak password. Scan your computer for things like keyloggers. More information regarding account security can be found [here](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201751664-Protecting-Your-Account).

> [{quoted}](name=LordYeven,realm=EUW,application-id=osqw6G4M,discussion-id=P2mZP9XN,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2016-10-02T17:54:10.177+0000)
>
> As we can't assist you with these sort of issues on the Boards, we suggest you [submit a ticket](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/requests/new) to Player Support. They'll be able to look into the issue and give you further assistance.
> However be aware that you are 100% responsible for things happening on your account.
> 
> To prevent this: make sure you logout every single time, do not choose a weak password. Scan your computer for things like keyloggers. More information regarding account security can be found [here](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201751664-Protecting-Your-Account).

If someone was hacked and it showed in IP logs to back their story then it isn't 100% his fault. If you are robbed at gun point it is't 100% your fault. Horrible way to answer this question imo. Just mention ticket and leave it at that, suggest better passwords. But don't act like every password is secured these are ratings and anything is crackable.

Sadly I am mainly on EUW, so I do not really see new post here (that's why the reply is really late), but anyways:  
Based on the Terms of Use you are responsible for any action on your account.   
Second: 

> don't act like every password is secured these are ratings and anything is crackable.

Where did I say that they aren't crackable? However, assuming that Riot stores them with a secure hash algorithm and salted, do you really think someone has (and uses) the computing power to bruteforce the password of a single simple LoL account which isn't in the most common lists of passwords? In an enormous amount of cases, it's simply phishing (free RP or something).

If you could specify what was wrong with an answer recommending better account security?

> [{quoted}](name=LordYeven,realm=EUW,application-id=osqw6G4M,discussion-id=P2mZP9XN,comment-id=000000000001,timestamp=2016-10-20T18:26:41.862+0000)
>
> Sadly I am mainly on EUW, so I do not really see new post here (that's why the reply is really late), but anyways:  
> Based on the Terms of Use you are responsible for any action on your account.   
> Second: 
> 
> Where did I say that they aren't crackable? However, assuming that Riot stores them with a secure hash algorithm and salted, do you really think someone has (and uses) the computing power to bruteforce the password of a single simple LoL account which isn't in the most common lists of passwords? In an enormous amount of cases, it's simply phishing (free RP or something).
> 
> If you could specify what was wrong with an answer recommending better account security?

Buddy, you have never heard of hash banks that are full of cracked hashes of almost any type. The database grows as users successfully crack hash or salted hash. User could of been victim of Social Engineering,  Virus,  Keylogger,  logging into open wire-less computer cafe' stores. I mean I can name thousands of ways I can get your password. I just wouldn't say something could be 100% his fault, he may of been a victim of his other account being sold (i.e Yahoo 400 million accounts information downloaded) He may not of been notified and the person who comprised his account saw it in that fashion as well. If I had your e-mail address more than likely you signed up for a site that has been hacked, more then likely I can pay my 10 dollars a month subscription to these databases and fu-k your life up. It seriously isn't that hard to realize account computerization is no longer a user error issue. This is an issue that is beyond the scope of fault.

> Social Engineering, Virus, Keylogger, logging into open wire-less computer cafe' stores

Arguable whether this is your responsibility or not. E.g. you would never login into your online bank account on a public wifi without using a VPN under your control. And social engineering can also be avoided. 

> if I had your e-mail address more than likely you signed up for a site that has been hacked, more than likely I can pay my 10 dollars a month subscription to these databases and fu-k your life up. 

How so? Okay assuming you get my email and a hashed+salted password. Let's even assume you somehow got the clear text password out of it (which is really hard). Now you have the account data for a site. Great, but my LoL password is different from every other password.

You can also change your password every x month. And cracking an SHA512 hashed password for every entry in these databases you mentioned is really really time and computing power consuming (and you rely on people using the same password everywhere).

  
You might be right that there are rare circumstances where it isn't your fault, but in most cases it is. I assume that a very high percentage of these cases are simple free RP phishing sites.

> [{quoted}](name=LordYeven,realm=EUW,application-id=osqw6G4M,discussion-id=P2mZP9XN,comment-id=00000000000100000000,timestamp=2016-10-23T14:28:11.886+0000)
>
> Arguable whether this is your responsibility or not. E.g. you would never login into your online bank account on a public wifi without using a VPN under your control. And social engineering can also be avoided. 
> 
> How so? Okay assuming you get my email and a hashed+salted password. Let's even assume you somehow got the clear text password out of it (which is really hard). Now you have the account data for a site. Great, but my LoL password is different from every other password.
> 
> You can also change your password every x month. And cracking an SHA512 hashed password for every entry in these databases you mentioned is really really time and computing power consuming (and you rely on people using the same password everywhere).
> 
>   
> You might be right that there are rare circumstances where it isn't your fault, but in most cases it is. I assume that a very high percentage of these cases are simple free RP phishing sites.

You know my friend, I think you are just impossible to just admit your statement was just wrong. So I am going to give you a link to an article of a guy who wanted to know how people get hacked and if it is really easy. His information that was taken was not only his Passwords (which he wasnt a victim of phishing)  but the information obtained would of ended his career. Had he not asked to be hacked, an individual could of ruined his career. So please go to school and understand that in the realm of computers anything is possible. 

http://www.networkworld.com/article/3038790/security/cautionary-tale-what-happens-after-daring-elite-hackers-to-hack-you.html

My only suggestion is that you understand blaming someone for hacking is extremely unethical and you should talk to an ADMIN and get information how simple it is to be compromised. I dont like making people paranoid but the only way you are safe is on a closed system. Because I am sure you as a person posting on this site, would be very simple to prove you wrong. Don't be stupid and ask to be proven wrong. Read the article, learn, and moving forward be respectful. Specially if you don't know the whole story, I have already seen Riot employees lift bans on people who have been hacked, who had people do similar things as this person posted and it be reversed. Don't be a dick plan and simple.
tbh this is probably a shitpost, you can gift someone right after adding them, they need to be added for a certain amount of time (maybe a week?)
It was 2 weeks, and now its 3 days I believe.

https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752964-Gifting-Guide-and-FAQ

> The player receiving a gift needs to have been on your buddy list for at least one day.

Damn they changed it again? I mean, it makes sense, people were complaining about having to wait but they should have something in place for security. Even if its optional, a pin or something of the sort would be a great solution for cases like this. It could even utilize a randomized onscreen keyboard if you think keyloggers are to blame.
The irony of this is mind boggling.

Thank you everyone and Targons Blade for your feedback. 

I have submitted a ticket and hoping to see some form of accountability out of this.
